TEXT: The applicant is a NORP citizen , born in DATE . When introducing his application he was serving an DATE prison sentence in GPE . Before the ORG he is represented by Mr PERSON , a lawyer practising in GPE .

On DATE the applicant arrived in GPE together with his family . They were accommodated at the asylum centre GPE , GPE . The applicant ’s arrival caused disturbances at the asylum centre as some of the refugees , coming also from the former GPE , thought to have recognised the applicant as a perpetrator of violent acts committed in DATE and DATE in the prison camp of PERSON during the armed conflict in the former GPE . ( The prison camp of PERSON was situated in the municipality of Čaplinja in the southern part of what is now GPE . It appears that this area was NORP controlled territory at the time of the alleged offences . )

The NORP police authorities were notified by the management of the asylum centre and during the following weeks a number of former prisoners from the prison camp , at that time residing in GPE , were interrogated by the police .
On DATE the applicant was arrested and charged with having illtreated and killed prisoners in the aforementioned prison camp . The applicant denied the charges .

On DATE ORG Retten i Roskilde ) decided to detain the applicant on remand as there were reasons to suspect that he had committed acts amounting to grievous bodily harm ( legemsangreb af særlig rå , brutal eller farlig karakter ) within in the meaning of LAW of LAW under particularly aggravating circumstances ( særdeles skærpende omstændigheder ) within the meaning of LAW of LAW . Furthermore , his detention on remand was based on the fear that he would evade prosecution or impede the investigations if he were at large during the proceedings .

On DATE counsel for the applicant requested the Chief of Police of Roskilde ( GPE i GPE ) to identify a number of assumed witnesses to the acts with which the applicant was charged , in order to interrogate them about the general conditions of the prison camp and their knowledge of the applicant ’s conduct in the camp . The witnesses included CARDINAL former prisoners from the camp , GPE , GPE and GPE ; CARDINAL former police officers who served in the camp while the applicant was there , C.J. and GPE , and the director of the camp during the applicant ’s stay there , PERSON In addition , the testimony of a person alleged to have been working with the applicant in the kitchen of the camp , GPE , was requested . These witnesses were presumed to reside in specific cities or villages in the former GPE and , with regard to some of the witnesses , a telephone number was mentioned . However , no precise addresses were submitted .
On DATE the Police of Roskilde requested ORG in GPE to contact the NORP and NORP authorities in order to obtain their assistance in identifying and finding the aforementioned persons .

It appears that the Chief of ORG informed the ORG , on DATE by phone and on DATE by fax , that it was not possible to identify the named persons since they were citizens of GPE and since the criminal acts had not taken place in GPE . Furthermore , on DATE , ORG informed the ORG that for the time being they had no opportunity to contact the persons in question .

On DATE counsel reminded the police that the aforementioned witnesses be summoned and requested that CARDINAL more witness , PERSON , be identified and interrogated . The letter contains no further information about this person .
Furthermore , on DATE counsel requested a lawyer practising in GPE to assist in providing the required evidence .

On DATE the Police of Roskilde again requested the ORG in GPE to provide information CARDINAL witnesses , including LOC and GPE On DATE a similar request was made to FAC in GPE . It appears that the police never received a reply to any of these requests .

On DATE an indictment ( amended on DATE ) was served on the applicant charging him with CARDINAL counts of grievous bodily harm committed against prisoners in the camp during DATE and DATE , on CARDINAL occasions causing the deaths of the victims .

In a letter dated DATE the NORP lawyer informed counsel that he had requested the local judicial authorities to interrogate the witnesses in question . However , due to the state of war in the area and lack of judges , the local authorities had not been able to carry out the interrogations required . The NORP lawyer had obtained , however , a written statement from GPE , which read , inter alia , as follows :
( Translation )
“ I , [ T.S. ] , ... give , at the request of PERSON from Čaplinja , this
Testimony :
In the period DATE and DATE I served as a prison camp director in PERSON , Čaplinja ...

I have known [ the applicant ] from DATE to DATE . In DATE the military authorities sent him to the camp in PERSON ... When he arrived to the camp he told me that he was a waiter of profession and that he had been working as such in GPE . As there was no trained staff in the kitchen in PERSON I sent him to work there and he was there all the time while he was in the camp . Thus , he has not been a guard - or a gaoler in the camp of PERSON , but worked as a prisoner in the kitchen ...

[ The applicant ] is married to PERSON from Čaplinja , daughter of PERSON , ... [ NORP the last period I noticed that NORP from the PERSON area expressed doubts as to his loyalty to the NORP as he had married a catholic ... and on several occasions there were fights between NORP from the Čaplinja area and NORP from the PERSON area ...
[ The applicant ] ... had during his stay in the camp neither opportunity , nor competence to ill - treat ... NORP prisoners and he has not done so .

In the camp of PERSON the NORP prisoners were separated in that CARDINAL group of NORP expressed NORP tendencies and behaved as such , whereas another group from PERSON expressed obvious fundamentalist tendencies and due to this there were more frequent conflicts .

They soon learned that [ the applicant ] ... had married PERSON , ... [ T]his group of NORP from PERSON , who expressed obvious fundamentalist tendencies , despised him , humiliated him and threatened him with physical harm as he had married the catholic NORP Jovanović and had given the children ... NORP names .
He had ... no authorisation from me , as director of the camp , to ... impose disciplinary sanctions and he could not have done so because the camp management would not have allowed it .
The group of prisoners from PERSON and from GPE addresses him as prison guard but he has never exercised such function ... he had the same rights and duties as all other prisoners .

The following witnesses can testify that [ the applicant ] ... did not , during his compulsorily detention in [ the camp ] ... , in any way ill - treat any NORP ... : [ FAC ] ... [ GPE ] ... [ GPE ] ... [ GPE ] ... [ M.B. ] ... [ GPE ] and [ C.J. ] ... and by these witnesses I have been told that they are willing to give testimony in court in GPE or in LOC in the case against [ the applicant ] and I am as director of the camp even willing to go to GPE and ... under oath give testimony ...

I stress that as a prison director I had an organised corps [ under my command ] which was necessary in order to meet the needs of the camp and , furthermore , I arranged ... a system in order to obtain information so that I would be informed of all events in [ the camp ] . However , in the period DATE and DATE I was not informed CARDINAL single time that [ the applicant ] was supposed to have ill - treated other prisoners while I had not been present .

To my profound belief this charge is raised against [ the applicant ] by fundamentalist NORP from the PERSON area , who have not been able to come to terms with the fact that [ the applicant ] is married to a NORP and has given his children NORP names ...
I solemnly declare that my statements in this testimony are correct and this ... testimony I am also prepared to give under oath before a court in GPE .
It is unclear from the material submitted whether this information was mentioned to the prosecution prior to the trial .
On DATE and DATE the applicant ’s counsel reminded the police of the request that the aforementioned witnesses be summoned to trial .

On DATE the Police of Roskilde urged ORG in GPE to contact the NORP authorities and request their assistance in order to find the QUANTITY witnesses and to summon them to appear before ORG of Eastern GPE ( PERSON ) on DATE . At the same time the police requested that CARDINAL other witnesses , also residing in former GPE , be summoned on behalf of the prosecution . These CARDINAL of whom had previously been interrogated by the police while residing in GPE - appeared at the hearing before ORG .

On DATE the Police of Roskilde , apparently occasioned by a negative reply from the ORG in GPE , forwarded their request to the NORP authorities for the summoning of the defence ’s witnesses through ORG in GPE .

The case was heard by ORG of Eastern Denmark from DATE until DATE , the ORG sitting with CARDINAL professional judges and a jury . During the hearing the applicant and CARDINAL witnesses were heard and written evidence was submitted , including a report prepared by ORG ( Retslægerådet ) . This report stated that the applicant was probably not insane prior to his arrival in GPE but that he subsequently developed a psychosis caused by external factors .

Among the aforementioned CARDINAL witnesses who were heard by ORG , there appears to have been witnesses called on the part of the prosecutor as well as the defence . Most of the witnesses were eyewitnesses to the events they gave evidence about . With regard to the CARDINAL most serious counts of violence committed against GPE and PERSON and leading to the death of the victims , several witnesses testified that the applicant had actively contributed to the violence committed against ORG , whereas CARDINAL witness had personally seen PERSON being ill - treated by the applicant .
With regard to the aforementioned CARDINAL witnesses requested by the defence the transcripts from the proceedings in ORG on DATE read as follows :
( Translation )
As regards [ GPE , GPE , GPE , C.J. , GPE , GPE , GPE , GPE ] no information has been submitted as to where they are presently residing .

[ The applicant ’s counsel ] requested that the hearing be adjourned for the purpose of obtaining further information as to whether and when these witnesses can be called . He referred in that respect to LAW subsection DATE , and LAW ( retsplejeloven

ORG objected to the principal request as well as to the alternative . He referred to exhibit ... and added that the police subsequent thereto and DATE had been on the line to ORG in GPE , who merely refers to the state of war . Everything possible has been attempted to reach the witnesses requested by counsel and under these circumstances [ it serves no purpose ] to adjourn the proceedings . In the opinion of the prosecution the conditions of Section CARDINAL , subsection CARDINAL , of ORG are not fulfilled .
Having deliberated [ the ORG ] ... made the following
Decision :
It is established that prior to and during the hearing the prosecution has availed itself of all possible means in order to reach the witnesses .

As it must be considered improbable , in the light of the conditions in GPE , that an adjournment of the hearing will lead to the completion of the testimonial evidence within a foreseeable period of time , the request for adjournment is denied .
As there exists in the present case quite extraordinary difficulties for the defence in the production of evidence , its request [ to read out the documents ] is exceptionally granted .
It is decided :
The hearing is not adjourned . It is allowed to read out in court [ the aforementioned documents ] .
[ The documents ] were read out .
The statement by ORG was the one given to the NORP lawyer ( cf . above ) .

After the hearing of evidence and the parties’ closing arguments the prosecution declared that it dropped the charges concerning CARDINAL of the CARDINAL counts for which the applicant was accordingly acquitted .

The jury was then asked to consider , primarily , whether the applicant was guilty in the CARDINAL remaining counts charging him with having committed acts , in the prison camp in DATE and DATE , amounting to grievous bodily harm within the meaning of LAW of LAW under particularly aggravated circumstances within the meaning of LAW of LAW and ORG and CARDINAL of LAW and Articles CARDINAL and CARDINAL of LAW . In the alternative they were asked to consider whether the acts in question amounted to grievous bodily harm within the meaning of Section CARDINAL of the Penal Code and the aforementioned Articles of LAW , only . In addition , the jury was asked whether , pursuant to LAW , subsection CARDINAL , of LAW , the applicant ’s sentence ought to exceed the maximum penalty of any of the provisions with which he was charged , with up to CARDINAL of the maximum .

The jury answered in the negative to the primary questions as well as to the alternative ones with regard to CARDINAL counts for which counts the applicant was subsequently acquitted . They answered in the affirmative to the primary questions with regard to CARDINAL of the counts and in the affirmative to the alternative questions with regard to the remaining CARDINAL counts . The jury also answered in the affirmative to the additional question relating to the applicant ’s sentence .

By judgment of CARDINAL DATE the applicant was accordingly convicted of CARDINAL counts in accordance with the jury ’s verdict . He was sentenced to DATE imprisonment . It was , furthermore , decided that the applicant be committed to a mental hospital until his prison sentence could be executed . Finally , it was decided that he be expelled from GPE subsequent to having served his prison sentence .

The applicant appealed against ORG judgment to ORG ( Højesteret ) which in the circumstances was only competent to determine whether procedural errors had been committed and to determine the sentence . ORG was on the other hand not empowered to determine the applicant ’s guilt .
On DATE the applicant ’s counsel requested ORG to make another attempt to find the CARDINAL witnesses in question .

On DATE the applicant ’s counsel submitted to ORG , inter alia , that the applicant be acquitted of CARDINAL counts and that the remainder of ORG judgment be quashed and remitted to ORG . In support of the claim he argued that ORG had made a procedural error by deciding not to adjourn the case in order to call in the CARDINAL witnesses . He invoked LAW ( d ) of the LAW .

It appears from the material submitted that , on DATE , ORG requested ORG to establish , through ORG and ORG , a contact with the CARDINAL witnesses . On DATE a similar request was made to ORG in GPE . The latter apparently never replied .
On DATE ORG received a fax from ORG reading as follows :
“ Regarding your request , please be informed that we are unable to identify the witnesses , based on the given data , therefore we are also unable to contact them .
Furthermore , we know nothing about the information indicated in your message saying that allegedly , the members of the MP of [ the ] NORP army served in the ORG camp in GPE in DATE .
In view of the above , we suggest [ y]ou contact ORG GPE and GPE through ORG .

Upon a request from the applicant ’s counsel the Chief of Police of GPE issued a note , on DATE , describing the efforts to get in contact with the CARDINAL witnesses . It read , inter alia , as follows :
( Translation )

[ The CARDINAL witnesses ] are either former prisoners in the camp [ GPE , GPE , GPE ] or NORP police officers / police soldiers [ C.J. , GPE , GPE ] and the director of the camp [ GPE ] . According to counsel , [ FAC ] is a former prisoner , which piece of information [ we ] can not confirm , or deny .

Information in the file concerning the persons in question is very sporadic and scant as they are merely briefly mentioned by their names by a few of the witnesses questioned . [ C.J. , GPE , GPE , GPE ] must be considered having committed criminal acts of violence in the camp .

On the basis of counsel ’s letter of DATE to ORG , to whom I have responded on an earlier occasion , I have again attempted to have the witnesses identified , cf . my enclosed note of DATE continued on CARDINAL DATE , although one will probably have to realise that the prospects of success are limited due to the fact that all the witnesses must be assumed to reside either in GPE or in a NORP dominated area of GPE .

Counsel has in my opinion no basis whatsoever for his remarks that the witnesses ‘ have a good knowledge of the conditions in the camp’ and will be able to ‘ contribute with information as to the circumstances surrounding the deaths of [ GPE and ORG as it is completely uncertain what they have observed - if anything at all . The value of testimonies from [ C.J. , GPE , GPE , GPE ] will in anticipation have to be distrusted as they very well may have participated in the violent acts in question or in other violent acts against the prisoners . It is in that respect notable that the written testimony from ... [ GPE ] , which counsel had the opportunity to read out [ in ORG ] ... appears untrustworthy and invented . The declaration was , it appears , given by [ PERSON ] at the request of [ the applicant ’s ] mother - in - law .

[ The Police of Roskilde ] have no knowledge about the former prisoners in the camp [ GPE , GPE , GPE and possibly FAC ] . It can hardly be ruled out that the said persons held a position in the camp similar to that of [ the applicant ] ( in charge of keeping order ) or enjoyed privileges similar to him , for which reason the credibility of their testimonies would be poor . In case of the persons in question being “ real ” prisoners it is plausible that a testimony from each of them would merely say that they did not observe any violence committed by [ the applicant ] against the prisoners . The value of such a statement would be very poor as the persons in question had a limited outlook from the buildings ... and a limited possibility of observing [ the applicant ] who was able to move freely around in the camp .

Thus , counsel has in no way rendered it probable that the requested examination of witnesses is required in order to clarify the matter ... However , as I have already mentioned I have again , through ORG , requested that the efforts to identify the witnesses be continued .

If the persons in question are identified I find it of the utmost importance that they give evidence in court in GPE as witness statements obtained in GPE or GPE in the circumstances hardly will have much probative force .
On DATE counsel sent a letter to the Prosecutor General reading , inter alia , as follows :
( Translation )
For your information I hereby enclose a copy of a letter of DATE from [ the aforementioned lawyer practising in GPE ] .

I draw your attention to the fact that the statements made by the witnesses in question are made in court without my presence . Thus , I have not had the opportunity to clarify the factual proposition , which the evidence tends to establish . Had I had that opportunity I would have made sure that [ the witnesses ] were asked about the deaths of [ GPE and GPE ] .
It is , however , evident from the material that it is possible to get in contact with the witnesses whom I have requested being heard .
The letter of DATE from the NORP lawyer reads inter alia :
( Translation )

“ Referring to your request of DATE ... ORG has requested the investigation judge at ORG to hear witnesses , and the witnesses [ PERSON , PERSON , and ORG ] have been heard . I forward the original transcript containing the testimonies .
The investigation judge ... will examine another CARDINAL witnesses , the testimonies of whom we will subsequently forward to you .
The testimony of PERSON reads , inter alia , as follows :
( Translation )

In [ the prison camp of PERSON ] I served as the director of [ the camp ] from DATE to CARDINAL DATE . I knew personally CARDINAL of the inmates , [ the applicant ] , and I am willing to declare under oath that he did not during the period in question , when he was in [ the camp ] , ill - treat or beat anyone , nor did he kill anyone . He worked in the kitchen as an assistant to the chef and I had as the director the monitoring function over [ the camp ] and he has , as I said , not beaten or killed anyone , nor has he in any way ill - treated anyone . If such things had happened I would have known as I was monitoring all inmates .
I further declare that no ill - treatment , fights or physical ill - treatment whatsoever took place in this [ camp ] , while I was the director of [ the camp ] .

The testimonies of PERSON , GPE , and further testimony given by C.J. , read in essence the same in that they maintained that they had not witnessed that the applicant had ill - treated other prisoners .

It appears that these testimonies were given in ORG on DATE , - except that of PERSON which was given on DATE an investigation judge and with a prosecutor being present . Before testifying , each witness were impressed with the duty to speak the truth and were told about the consequences of making false statements .
On DATE the police authorities in GPE received a radiogram from ORG reading as follows :
Concerning your message , please be advised that ... we were not able to find the mentioned persons and contact ... them .
These persons are in GPE and at this territory of our country ... because of consequences of war ... the legal authorities are not yet able to [ carry out their ] ... functions .
We also mention that these persons were indirectly involved in tragic events in camp “ Dretelj ” ... [ W]e advised you about these details earlier .
We suppose that these persons for that reason avoid to stay at [ the ] territory of our country .
On DATE the applicant ’s counsel sent a letter to ORG , which reads as follows :
( Translation )
“ Referring to your letter of DATE I shall hereby address [ the note ] of CARDINAL DATE from the Chief of Police of GPE .
Of the CARDINAL witnesses I mention in my letter of DATE to ORG there is , through [ the NORP lawyer ] , established a contact to four , i.e. [ M.B. , C.J. , GPE and GPE ] . ... .

In the High Court ’s decision concerning the adjournment of the case in order to examine the CARDINAL witnesses nothing is said about the relevance of the witnesses for the case . ORG decision is solely reasoned by the difficulties which had been involved - and are presumed to continue to be involved - in getting in contact with the witnesses .

Already at an early stage the applicant wanted the hearing of the CARDINAL witnesses , whom he firmly believes can contribute with essential information , not least in order to illuminate the circumstances concerning the deaths of [ GPE and GPE ] .

The letters to [ the NORP lawyer ] show that it has been possible to get in contact with , so far , CARDINAL out of the CARDINAL witnesses and , therefore , to my mind a continued effort to call these witnesses can not be considered futile .

Furthermore , I refer to the possibility of having a court hearing of the witnesses in their home country with the participation of a NORP prosecutor and myself . Such a hearing can clarify whether the witnesses have any relevant information and , if so , what .

The remark made by the police that a number of the witnesses , whom I have requested be heard , possibly had a position in the camp similar to that of [ the applicant ] or privileges similar to his is in my opinion without substance .
I maintain , therefore , that the efforts to get in contact with the CARDINAL witnesses and obtain their testimony be continued .
From a letter of CARDINAL DATE from the Chief of Police of GPE to ORG it appears that the police had not then received any further information about the witnesses .
In reply to a letter from the applicant ’s counsel requesting further information relating to the deaths of GPE and GPE , the NORP lawyer replied , on DATE , inter alia , as follows :
( Translation )
The public prosecutor has informed me that [ the applicant ] ... was an ordinary prisoner and that , during his stay in [ the camp ] , he had no special authority .

As regards the death of [ GPE ] it has been established that he died on DATE and that he was hit in the head with a wooden club by a person named PERSON , a prisoner who was a NORP and it has been established that this person had been insane for DATE ... This piece of information can be confirmed by ORG .
In DATE the same , PERSON , ... hit [ PERSON ] and he died also in [ the camp ] from the strokes .
The accused in both cases , for killing [ GPE ] and [ PERSON ] , is the insane man ... PERSON and the case has been investigated by the judicial authorities .

The investigation judge at ORG has told me that they no longer have the competence to interrogate and supervise the defence for [ the applicant ] as there has been set up an ORG in GPE for war crimes committed in former GPE and as the national courts at the request of ORG in the GPE are obliged to initiate certain investigations .
On DATE ORG upheld ORG judgment . The judgment reads inter alia :
( Translation )

As regards the claim that ORG judgment be quashed and the case remitted to ORG , [ the applicant ] has argued that ORG decision of CARDINAL DATE not to adjourn the case in order to find and hear [ the CARDINAL witnesses ] , amounts to a procedural error pursuant to LAW and LAW , subsection CARDINAL , of the LAW in conjunction with LAW ( d ) of the LAW . [ The applicant ] claims , furthermore , that ORG erred by not employing the special standard of proof adopted in the judgment ... , having regard to [ the applicant ’s ] mental state .
ORG reasoning :

As ORG agrees with the reasoning of ORG , in its decision of DATE , ORG finds that no procedural error has been committed by ORG by proceeding with the case on the basis of the testimonies in their possession , cf . Section CARDINAL of ORG . Nor has ORG erred in relation to the standard of proof adopted in judgment ... , which must be considered to express a general principle in criminal procedure that the accused must enjoy the benefit of all reasonable doubt . Thus , [ the applicant ’s ] claim that the judgment be quashed and the case remitted [ to ORG ] is rejected .
It is ordered :
ORG judgment is upheld .
